channel.title: Should marijuana be legalised?
channel.description:
Well at the moment im really pissed off. Im from the west midlands (England) And recently the police are cracking down HARD on weed dealers. Now usually this wouldn't be a problem, apart from the fact that prices around here have risen from around £15 (about $28, still alot in US terms) for an eigth (3.5 grams) to £25 (About $45) and its hard to get hold off.
Now consider this, we have alot of potheads around here, and dealers are falling short. They cant afford to buy anymore and when they do its hard to obtain because the police have been cracking down, meanwhile harder drugs are alot cheaper and fairly easy to obtain. What are they going to do?
Another thing that really annoys me is the education we get in the U.K over drugs. I can renember throughout my yonger years in secondary and primary school we would have lessons pretty much every week telling us about how bad marijuana is and how easy it is to get addicted. They tell you all the bad facts and lie to you to convince you to avoid the magical herb. Now with all these lies and controvesy lieing in your head, most people will at least try it once, and it makes you think. If its relitivly harmless and hard to get addicted, what about all the other things the goverment have been trying to make us avoid?
I think at least the youth of today should be told the pro's and con's of cannabis, not just lies to make sure we avoid it. Also im looked down upon by society because i smoke it. So what? I know its not good for me but its my life and I make my own choices, just like somebody else may choose to get a tatoo or drink.
Personally im sick of all the crap the goverment have been telling us to avoid something that shouldn't even take priority over alcohol. If it was legalised and education over drugs was imrpoved to give us the facts not the lies, maybe this country wouldnt be so bad?
I don't know, what are your opinions?

Get real man.

Eh Pretty Easy:

It shouldn’t be legalized, since the whole world is crappy already, we don’t want/need people saying “Crack, want some crack?” when you’re going to lunch.

This debate is about marijuana, not crack. The legalization of marijuana will not effect the crack smokers. As far as I’m concerned if people want to smoke crack let them but you can keep it far away from me.

The thing is, people don’t care if it’s illegal or not. If someone wants to smoke marijuana, they are going to do it. If someone wants to drink under aged, they will do it.

Anyways, although I would rather decriminalization(because it would do me better) here are some benefits of legalizing marijuana.

Well, this is just California. Imagine the entire US.

California NORML estimates that a legal market for marijuana could yield the state $1.5 - $2.5 billion. A basic $1 per joint excise tax would yield about $1 billion to the state, while the state would save over $150 million in enforcement costs for arrests, prosecutions and prison. Additional benefits would accrue from sales taxes and spinoff industries. Total retail sales of marijuana would be on the order of $3-$5 billion, with total economic impact of $8-$13 billion including spinoff industries such as coffeehouses, tourism, and industrial hemp.

I’m not so much in the mood for typing right now so I thought I would quote some stuff from various websites.

Ever wake up feeling really hung over from a night of smoking out? Thought not. Throw in some heavy drinking, though, and you'll awake feeling like death itself (in fact, alcohol poisoning is a real risk). No one overdoses on marijuana because it has a negligible therapeutic ratio; that is, you don't have to use much to get the desired effect. Why then is one drug available from corner stores and allowed to be promoted at bowling tournaments, whereas the other you have to get from a pimply guy with a mullet you knew vaguely in high school, who hands you something dodgy-looking in a sandwich baggie? Quit the hypocrisy and make these intoxicants equally available.
When corn sells for a few dollars a bushel and pot goes for $70,000 a bushel, guess which one cash-strapped midwestern farmers are going to grow? ... Marijuana has replaced corn as America's top cash crop, and is really tough to detect tucked away in fields of corn. A legal regime that turns ordinary farmers into the worst class of offenders (growers) has something deeply wrong with it.
The war on drugs will only be won if we're willing to turn our country into a police state, and that is what these draconian laws are doing for us.
I especially agree with this. I mean billions and billions of dollars are spent to prevent Joe Blow from smoking marijuana. Although they haven't gotten too far with that other then putting law abiding citizens(except for the marijuana laws of course) in jail or making them pay massive fines with a criminal record. And lets not forget intruding their privacy and rights.
Stiffer sentencing has meant jails overcrowded with drug offenders, forcing the early release of violent criminals - inclluding murderers - to make room for guys who've been handed mandatory life terms without the possibility of parole for their "third strike." America is now the world's greatest jailor nation, with a prison population consisting overwhelmingly of drug offenders. On average, we sentence nonviolent drug offenders to five times more jail time than those convicted of manslaughter.
Marijuana creates pacifism and is a stress reliever Will decrease the crime rate if the herb is readily available. It will eliminate the need of an underground subculture Marijuana has medicinal values No one has ever died from smoking marijuana [unlike the 100,000 people who die every year from alcohol] Pot enhances creativity

Oh and I don’t know if pot smokers owe tax payers an apology or not after reading this:

According to the FBI, 401,982 Americans were arrested nationwide for marijuana offenses in 1980. By 1999, a record 704,812 were nabbed, 88 percent of them for possession rather than trafficking. Since cannabis arrests constitute 44 percent of all drug apprehensions, the [b]Marijuana Policy Project (MPP) estimates that the government's war on pot smokers costs taxpayers $9.2 billion annually.[/b]

Well I guess I’ll go do something else. I know theres other benefits, and probably some cons.
